quote: What a weekend, the perfect event experience. Great courses. Amazing volunteers. Spectacular race amenities such as camping, food, and showers. This is a race that both Nankmans would recommend.
5th female gravel race, 3rd female mountain bike race; 2nd for those that did both races

My plan was to really concentrate on pacing myself. I tend to go out too fast then end up 'death marching' the last 20 or so miles of a race, so, when we hit a few rollers, I forced myself to sit back & spin while others kept the intensity up.
I am really, really happy with my ride. I now have a really good feel for what type of pace I can sustain for that type of distance.
Sometimes finishing in fourth can be disheartening, but this time I knew I had given it everything I could
16th male gravel, 28th mountain bike (mens field of almost 100 for gravel and over 100 for mtb); 12th combined

Make sure your tire sealant is fresh and you carry flat fixing items; flat tires were numerous both days including Joel who did get two flats on the gravel day. Luckily Saucon Valley Bikes supplied us with lots of tubes and sealant to take along on this trip so flats could be fixed.
60 miles of gravel racing on my Devote Advanced Saturday and 60 miles of mountain biking on some amazing single track on my Piqued Advanced Pro 29 Sunday
Finished third for the Singlespeed category with a 34x20 gea[ring]

Temperature swings are quite possible. For this year racers woke to frost on the ground both days and with an 8am start it was still quite cold in the mornings but warmed up to the 60s/70s by the end of the race.
It was cold at the start, but it promised to warm up quickly and be a beautiful day in the Ouachitas.
The 61-mile course has a couple of moderate climbs in the first 25 miles, followed by mostly flat roads leading up to one final half-mile climb that tops out four miles from the finish line.
Creek crossings were numerous at both races, be ready for wet feet.
Get your climbing legs ready, both days have significant climbing; they make your legs hurt but are worth the effort.
The first 8.5 miles were a little pavement & some gravel
After numerous mudholes and creeks, the climb started
I tend to go out too fast then end up 'death marching' the last 20 or so miles of a race, so, when we hit a few rollers, I forced myself to sit back & spin while others kept the intensity up.
With the races being no more than three to six hours for us we easily carried all we needed including all out Honey Stinger nutrition in our back pockets.
The racing was fairly calm at the start, and a large front group of around 30 to 40 riders was together as we hit the first checkpoint at mile 15.
The Ouachita Challenge had all of the above, getting gold stars for all the categories and had the full conglomeration of all the things a racer can want and need.
Camping Friday and Saturday night was allowed directly on the school campus, with racers parking their vans and setting up their tents at various locations around the grounds.

Oh my, this was just top notch... The Ouachita Challenge rose above and beyond in the food category. There was post race food on Sunday of personal pizzas for each racer which hit the spot perfectly after 60 miles of tough mountain biking.
They were all so amazing. Every person involved with this race was just so nice, caring, involved, and friendly. One could tell they all just want to race to be a success.
Courses both days were well marked with volunteers at road crossings and trail intersections directing racers.
Both days had ample aid stations that offered both nutrition and hydration.

Podium awards were for the top three each day and then the top winner overall for the combined double event. Awards were cash; can never go wrong with that. A race photographer was present both days taking some amazing photos for purchase.
The race started from Oden, AR at 8:00 to the sound of a ringing church bell

All riding and everything having to do with the race was based out of the school complex in Oden. This was the absolutely perfect hub. Registration, parking, and the race start/finish were all right there.
